review_title: Way too much overtime and low pay/No investment in staff

cons:
Very poor investment in staff. I watch good people leave all the time for better jobs and the people who can't get something better stay because they don't have options. HR is a joke and is no advocate for staff.
The work culture is one of constant overwork with more and more being asked of people as staff leaves and is not replaced. There is almost no support for onboarding new people so they don't know how to do things, but can't find help from supervisors or other team members. job_title: Marketing Communications Associate in Washington, DC
pros: I met some great people here and generally speaking, enjoyed the work. The people at mid and lower levels are great, full of passion and talent. My specific position has allowed for a lot of exploration of new skills and mentorship within my department. Figuring out the return to work plan has been fairly flexible and my dept leadership is keen on getting everyone’s feedback. (Not sure what it’s like for other depts though.) There’s a good amount of interesting projects to work on. Getting to see programs in action and their impact is great! Paid holidays, good vacation time, and retirement match.
cons:
World Learning wants to be globally minded but have yet to figure out a system where employees can be more mobile/live abroad/work where and how they do their best. Work has changed so much in the last few years but HR and leadership seem very stagnant and too traditional for me. Not nearly at the level of innovation that they should be. Inefficient systems, siloed communication. Lots of jargon, especially at the upper levels.

High performance isn’t really rewarded as much as it could be. I’ve received various empty promises and had things fall through, probably because there’s no promotion, hiring, or pay transparency. I’ve also had some projects handed to me and my teammates in the name of “professional advancement” but it’s really just work well above our pay grade with little to no guidance or training.

I learn a ton from my coworkers and enjoy my time here for the most part, but the higher up positions are the super well paid people who seem to be fine with just keeping the status quo as long as they’re making the rich, out of touch board members happy. Senior leadership is also where you’ll find a lot of discrepancies with what the org says are its core values. Lots of talk, but doesn’t ever seem to be much tangible action. Ridiculous that they still don’t share salary ranges for open positions. I know good DEI work takes time but like… this is too much time. And if you ask HR about any changes all you get is “we’re working on it, it’ll happen at some point… maybe.”

I def would not have stayed working here as long as I have if I weren’t for a great manager relationship and a few key coworkers and fun projects that have made it worthwhile overall.

pros: Great co-workers, opportunities for advancement, high-quality, mission-driven work

pros: Easy to communicate with and open team mentality
cons: At times vague approach with tasks

pros: I met and worked with some great colleagues passionate about the work. Overall, I found that working at World Learning was a solid way to get my foot in the door in the international NGO field and develop valuable professional experience.
cons:
Having moved to a new company with transparent, non-hierarchical communication, supportive and friendly management, highly effective onboarding and training processes, and room for internal mobility, I feel like leaving World Learning was akin to leaving a toxic relationship.

As many others have said, your experience at World Learning significantly depends on your team and your manager. Unfortunately, I found my team environment to be quite toxic. My managers did not advocate for me and misinformed me about company policy regarding promotions/raises and taking time off. On an interpersonal level, I found that my managers were often belittling, undermining, and insincere. Frustration from overwork or disorganization was clearly channeled downward. Half of my team left in less than six months this past year due to the extreme lack of opportunity for growth, limited mobility, and low pay. The management structure seems to reward those who discourage employees under them from seeking advancement and opportunities, and push out those who attempt to rock the boat. The lack of transparency from the top down and hierarchical communication structure makes it incredibly difficult to navigate this organization and sometimes even inhibits your ability to work efficiently. Having to go through very specific communication channels to make a request or ask a question about policy (your supervisor forwards your inquiry to their supervisor and so forth), feels very disempowering (my rank is too low to ask the right person this question?) and once again, limits transparency by excluding you from these conversations that directly concern you. In general, my department seemed to promote a culture of fear around contacting HR directly with questions about company policy or position advancement, allowing management to shut down any requests open discussion about these topics.

Talking to colleagues from outside of my team, we found disturbing pay/annual raise discrepancies between us. There was little consistency or reasonable explanation for these discrepancies between the same positions on different teams, and no transparency for the process of receiving a promotion (or rejection for that matter). 

I never felt like I was properly trained to do my job. Although I eventually learned to do my job well, I was really left to sink or swim from the beginning, causing a lot of unnecessary stress. I felt like I was inconveniencing others by asking for help. I also found, shockingly, that some tasks or responsibilities I was assigned, no one else on my team had institutional knowledge of how to do, largely due to high turnover and routine brain drain, leaving me to spend significant amount of time figuring out these processes from scratch. Most alarmingly, I felt that the lack of consistent training and standardized processes left gaps regarding privacy and confidentiality of our clients, as well as general client care. I felt like my lack of official training in these areas was a huge disservice to our clients.

Diversity & Inclusion is woefully underprioritized at World Learning. Talk of diversity and inclusion was very often reactive rather than proactive, with little transparency around efforts to improve or institutions/resources in place to encourage Diversity & Inclusion. This is critically important for an international NGO in the 21st century, especially one that has been known to underserve staff members of color and promote white saviorism abroad in the past.

As others have pointed out, the rollback of benefits due to COVID-19 was disruptive and, once again, not transparent. Our annual cost of living adjustment was cancelled for two year in a row, vacation time rollover was cancelled, professional development funds were suspended, and 403b matching was cancelled. At first, the latter two expenses being cancelled made sense due to the massive loss of income, but after finances were (supposedly) stabilized and our benefits were not reinstated, it felt like a prolonged excuse not to give us vacation time or cost of living adjustment without an honest explanation.

It's also worth noting that most of the positive reviews of this organization in the last year are from middle or upper management, including new hires. I've found this laughably insincere and believe this illustrates the dishonesty in management at World Learning.

In summary, depending on the team you join, working for World Learning may be worth it if you're just looking to get your foot in the door, but make sure to having an escape plan in mind if you find yourself in a situation similar to mine.

review_title: Stuck in a cycle of leadership transition and instability
pros: inspiring co-workers. programs are great for participants and those of us that work on them.
cons: Leadership has gone through multiple transitions over the last few years. Its really disconcerting. Lots of instability before covid and only worse during covid. If our organization didn't get the PPP funds we did, we'd likely be collapsing or having to use more of the unrestricted endowment funds that the organization has already been digging into. I won't be here for long and will miss my colleagues, but its toxic at the leadership level. I am also concerned that donors see on the organizational 990 that World Learning finds a way to come close to a break even budget but net assets are going down--and not just because of depreciation--and revenue in general is going down (collapsed in 2020 with covid). If the organization loses more donors or it loses any of its government contracts, then its likely to shrink tremendously or collapse--just my hypothesis but its pretty tenuous. SIT graduate institute is already a failed school (not philosophically, but financially and the leadership is inept).

pros: The government funded work is going to get a boost with the Biden Administration. My cube mates if we were still in cubes. Being able to telework.
cons: Try making it in DC on the wages they pay for program associates. Its terrible. I have to live with 6 people and one bathroom. Really. DC is so expensive. And I'm not one of the privileged white savior rich kid types that can make it so easy here in DC. Its hard being BIPOC in this organization, particularly with the patronizing language of the leadership and no chance to advance (and professional development has been cut repeatedly over the last few years--even before Covid). The Diversity Abroad evaluation that is happening is just going to gloss over the issues and sit on a shelf like all the 'plans' the leadership comes up with. They say there aren't going to be more layoffs...but everyone knows its likely to happen again before the end of 2021. SIT is running a huge deficit that hurts the whole organization because they're 15 years behind the rest of the field and have a degree program that's worth nothing (and no, adding a PhD program doesn't elevate SIT...just makes it look even more like a ripoff than before).

review_title: Top of the Industry in Culture & Values
pros:
I worked at World Learning for nearly 4 years and it was the best place I have ever worked. I came in as a mid-career. I know several co-workers who came in as interns or early career and quickly moved up the hierarchy. There are a lot of leadership development opportunities within the organization from leading a working group to being promoted into management. That promotion ability does depend on your program, but in the 4 years I was there several colleagues were promoted at least once, and many times twice in that time period. 

The work and office culture was one of the best I've ever experienced. Other organizations I've worked for talk a good game, but World Learning walks the walk. There will be times you work after hours or have busy weeks, but managers are flexible about work/life balance when those busy times are over. In non-Covid times there are lots of opportunities to take part in after hours fun if that's your thing, or not if that's your thing too. Many of my friends outside of work came from my time at World Learning even though we've all since moved on. 

Ultimately, like any organization there will be pros and cons, but the office culture, work/life balance, in-house professional development, and org focus on living their values made World Learning one of the best places I've worked. And I don't say that lightly.
cons:
Like any non-profit, especially one funded by government contracts, the pay is not what you'll find in for-profit industry (it's pretty standard for non-profit though and I've worked in several). World Learning does pay more than their competitors and what they can't pay in higher salary or Cadillac benefits, they make up for in work/life balance and culture where they can. One con is that this can be limited based on your manager, though they try to make most flexibility standard across programs/teams/managers. If you bring up any issues in this area, leadership will listen and try to institute fair policies though, like any organization, it can seem slow moving.

Your job satisfaction can depend on your manager, like any organization there were a few colleagues I knew having a hard time because of who their manager was or because of which project they worked on. If it was a project issue, those colleagues made lateral moves to other departments/projects as new funding is always coming in and opportunities open up. If dissatisfaction was manager-based, colleagues often did the same - moved laterally to new teams or projects. World Learning is like any organization where there are some bad managers, but I had a pretty central view of the organization and gauge the bad:good ratio to be about 10:90.

review_title: Great organization to start your career in international development
pros: You will have the opportunity to work with some really great, passionate, and enthusiastic people. The culture of World Learning in DC is friendly, inviting, and non-competitive. They value hard work and the staff regardless of level. There is room for personal and professional growth in the organization, especially if you start off as an intern or Program Assistant. You can make your way up to Program and Senior Program Officer with time and dedication. Depending on the team and project there is opportunity to travel internationally which has its perks. There is always international groups coming and going in the office so you also meet very interesting people around the world. Vacation and benefits are good, and salary is competitive to DC development orgs. World Learning recognizes all national holidays and is even closed for the whole week of Christmas to New Years, so you don't have to use any vacation time.
cons: Many times there is a culture of favoritism shown by senior management. It would be wise to get on the good side of the managers and directors early on. You do have fend and lookout for yourself, so if you want a raise or title change then you have to go after it. If you want to be noticed, then you need to make it apparent to do so.

pros:
World Learning is a family friendly employer in that they generally allow flexible hours and have recently instituted a telework policy that allows approved employees to work 1 day/week at home.  While my personal manager is very flexible on this, I know of others who are inherently suspicious to telework and aren't inclined to trust employees to implement this honestly.  

If you are willing to work hard and play the system, World Learning is an employer that will provide you with new opportunities to grow professionally.

Downtown location is highly convenient.

There are some excellent individuals who work here.
cons:
World Learning, in practice, isn't always aligned with its values. They have grown in recent years, but this growth has led to ineffective strategy development and a cadre of senior managers that demonstrate an inability to think strategically and effectively implement new initiatives in a timely manner.  Decision making is emotionally and relationship driven.  This leads to a stressful working environment.  

Frustrations across junior staff are high and visible.  There is no internal professional development.

pros: Made some great friends here
cons: Management is old and not accepting of the inevitability of change

review_title: Great or absolutely horrible, depending on your supervisor and team.
pros: The younger staff at the organization are wonderful and a lot of fun to work with. If you are interested in learning to work on US government grants and contracts this is a good organizations to work for, particularly if you are interested in professional and educational exchange programs.
cons: There are a lot of individuals with poor management skills that have been promoted into senior management positions, which is worsened by an overall lack of transparency in hiring and promotion practices. My immediate supervisors were generally always great to work for, but poor management within the overall organization made it hard to enjoy the day to day. There is also little room for growth and advancement and little appreciation for those who go above and beyond the call of duty.

review_title: Forward-focused organization with a friendly culture
pros: It's great to work for an organization working for positive change in the world. Projects involve people from all over the world, and the people who work here are interesting, fun, and extremely competent. Lots of opportunities for professional development, lots of internal mobility. Positive, fun work environment.
cons: The structure of projects means that people advance only to fill vacancies, and some projects don't have much turnover at the program officer level. You need to show initiative in order to advance. Entry-level pay is modest but comparable to other organizations.

pros: Fellow employees are pretty great to work with across the board. World Learning tends to have an open and welcoming office environment with motivating work without being competitive.
cons: Program Associate level jobs pay at such a low rate (and managerial quality is so scattered) that people don't stick around for very long. This means seemingly endless rounds of interviewing for new Program Associates and a work culture that can change completely within the space of a few months, lacking consistency.

review_title: Your experience will depend what team or project you are working on!
pros: Good and collaborative working atmosphere on most teams; where input from all levels is welcomed and professional development is fostered.
cons: Not all teams allow for professional development, especially at the Intern or Program Associate level.  Opportunities or advancement are minimal within teams, resulting in a lot of turnover at the Program Associate level.

pros:
-Co-workers/colleagues are friendly and supportive
-Fairly laid back environment

- Work is meaningful
cons:

-Neo-liberal policies bizarrely enough in SIT Study Abroad even though their programs espouse the exact opposite

review_title: Great place for a first job
pros: good camaraderie with junior staffers. Nice location in DC. Numerous professional networking opportunities with people from all corners of the globe.
cons: long hours and low salaries for associates. no bonuses. They job really depends on which manager you draw as a boss. Many of them are good people who are just ill suited for the job. My first manager was perving on me during my first day of work and had to be transferred. My second manager, who lasted only a few months, was a super cool person, but totally unmotivated. My last manager was even worse.

pros: WL's knowledge of the education and exchange field is second to none. People have a real sense of mission and are not just chasing money. Inclusion is a value that WL lives in both its project work and its own staffing. I've worked for a half dozen development organizations, many of which I really enjoyed.  WL's people and processes are as good as any of my previous employers.
cons: Sometimes we underestimate ourselves, in my opinion.

pros: Interesting work.  Wonderful students at the Graduate Institute.  Satisfying place to work if you can take initiative and are a self-starter.
cons: Hit or miss depending on your department.  Seems to be little interest in developing talent or opportunities for current employees at the Brattleboro site.   HR did not have a handle on what was going on in individual departments resulting in some extraordinarily poor treatment of certain employees.

review_title: Great first job in DC; fun workplace with education exchange programs

cons: Salaries in this field in general are just low, and this is on par. Also, it can take a while to advance beyond your initial hiring position
